data.text: @tmu @dgolding Right, I'm just thinking - could report it in text, or just visually, or both. I'm running out of text in the "main" tweet but could add it into the analysis section. Also not too hard. But I think I quite like the visual line version.

@dave_andersen @dgolding As @dgolding mentioned, I do that with my squinty eyes automatically every day. It helps me remember when it was last like now and what I should be thinking about. Also maybe what did I do in the past that I would do differently now.
@dgolding @tmu Hm. Could just plot the current level as a horizontal line so you can see how it compares to all of history. That's pretty easy to add...
@tmu @dave_andersen I always do this - draw a horizontal line and trace backwards. This is a great FR

@dave_andersen Got it.  one big change i am looking for is making masks optional at schools. I think the impact on socialization and kids well being is significant and it's time to make masks optional (until the next wave...). Thanks.

@MeNoAreNoNiceG2 It has - but last week's estimate has now remained roughly consistent with this week's update (and matches what we're hearing from SGTF), which is why I think it's finally getting things more right.

But yes, nowcast is a model, not a measurement, and it could totally be off.

@dave_andersen It should also be pointed out that the CDC Nowcast has consistently overestimated the prevalence of BA.2.  Two weeks ago, the Nowcast had BA.2 at around 4% as of the week of 2/12.  The actual number turned out to be 2%.

@stavgil in behavior as cases continue to decline, and that's likely a sane path forward. But I do like reporting both metrics because the risk for, e.g., unvaccinated & not previously infected (rare birds) or immunocompromised folks remains fairly high, and we should aim for lower.

@stavgil I agree it's time to think about the path. _Big_ changes are unwise, because we don't know how much of a change shifts us above an Rt of 1 (where cases start increasing). But it's not like we have huge statewide mandates to relax, so we're likely to see piecewise shifts

3/n
